personal.name: Lovely Pearl B. Alan
personal.title: BSIT Student - Web & App Development | Aspiring Data Analyst
personal.summary: Motivated and detail-oriented BSIT student specializing in web and app development with a strong foundation in database management, programming, and front-end development. Recognized as a President's Lister and proven leader in student organizations. Developed a Laravel-based Good Moral Certificate System as capstone project and led growth initiatives as JPCS President.

salary_location.current_status: Final year BSIT student (graduating 2026), seeking entry-level opportunities

philippines_local.reasoning: Aligned with Philippine junior analyst market rate, reflects strong academic record and leadership experience

international_remote.reasoning: Competitive for remote junior analyst in international companies, accounts for Philippines cost of living

demonstrated_skills: Served as President of the Junior Philippine Computer Society – SPUP Chapter, leading 70+ members and overseeing organization-wide projects and events.

Held multiple leadership roles in the Paulinian Student Government, including Executive Secretary, Assistant Secretary, and Associate Justice, coordinating university-wide initiatives and strategic planning.
Organized and facilitated high-impact campus events such as BALAY: Ethical Leadership Workshop, the World Teachers’ Day Celebration, and the International Assembly of Youth for UNESCO.
Coordinated cross-functional teams during cultural exchange programs and emergency response projects, demonstrating strong collaboration, communication, and decision-making skills.

Applied advanced technical and analytical skills in coursework, achieving strong grades in key subjects such as Advanced Database Systems (1.25), Object-Oriented Programming (1.00), and Strategic Planning for ERP (1.00).
Collaborated effectively on a capstone project using Git, Slack, and virtual communication tools, presenting deliverables to faculty and stakeholders.

signature_project.name: Good Moral Application and Monitoring System
signature_project.description: A web-based system to digitize and streamline the good moral certificate process for students.
signature_project.situation: Manual certificate processing was slow and paper-based, requiring students to visit multiple offices.
signature_project.task: Develop a web application to automate the certificate request and approval process.
action: Led the 3-person development team throughout the semester
Handled all programming and technical implementation
Designed the database schema for student records and certificate tracking
Developed the full application using Laravel framework with MySQL backend
Implemented features for student requests and administrator approvals
Created user interfaces for students and administrators
Conducted testing and presented the project at the Capstone Research Showcase

result.outcome: Successfully completed capstone project with working web application
result.grade: Received strong grade and positive faculty feedback
result.functionality: System allows students to request certificates online and administrators to approve them digitally

signature_project.business_impact: Demonstrated ability to build a full-stack web application solving a real campus problem.

basic_data_work.description: Worked with Excel for academic and organizational tasks
techniques_used: Pivot tables for simple data analysis
basic_data_work.outcome: Developed proficiency with Excel through coursework and student government responsibilities

projects_star_format.project_name: Good Moral Application and Monitoring System (Capstone Project)
projects_star_format.budget_managed: Academic project (₱15,000 allocated for hosting and testing)

situation.context: St. Paul University Philippines processed 500+ good moral certificate requests annually using a manual paper-based system
situation.problem: Manual processing took 5-7 days with 15% error rate due to data entry mistakes, lost paperwork, and inefficient approval workflows
situation.business_impact: Student frustration, administrative burden on 3 staff members spending 40+ hours/month, inability to track requests or generate reports
situation.stakeholders: 200+ students requesting certificates annually, 3 administrative staff, 1 Dean for approvals, IT department

task.primary_responsibility: Lead the 3-person team to design and build a web-based certificate request system
task.specific_role: Team leader and sole programmer - handled all technical implementation
success_criteria: Create working web application for certificate requests
task.constraints: One semester timeline, academic coursework alongside capstone, learning Laravel framework during development

action.overview: Led a 3-person team through one semester to build a complete web-based certificate request system using Laravel
my_responsibilities: Handled all programming and technical implementation
Designed database schema for student records and certificate tracking
Developed Laravel MVC application with authentication and CRUD operations
Created student interface for submitting certificate requests
Built admin interface for reviewing and approving requests
Implemented form validation and basic security features
Coordinated with team members on project requirements and timeline
Presented final project at Capstone Research Showcase
team_collaboration: Led project planning and task coordination
Held regular team meetings throughout semester

result.outcome: Successfully completed working web application within semester timeline
result.functionality: System allows students to submit certificate requests online and administrators to review and approve them digitally
result.grade: Received strong grade on capstone project
result.presentation: Successfully demonstrated system functionality at Capstone Research Showcase
result.faculty_feedback: Positive feedback from faculty on technical implementation and project execution

career_goals.team_size: Executive board of 8, coordinating 70 total members

situation.context: Junior Philippine Computer Society (JPCS) chapter at St. Paul University with declining membership
situation.problem: Membership had dropped from 60 to 50 members over 2 years (17% decline), low event attendance (15-20 people), and lack of engagement
situation.business_impact: Reduced club relevance, fewer resources from university, inability to host larger events, limited networking opportunities for CS students
situation.stakeholders: 50 current members, 200+ potential members (CS students), 8 executive board members, faculty advisor, university student affairs office

task.primary_responsibility: Reverse membership decline, increase engagement, and establish JPCS as premier tech organization on campus
task.specific_role: President - set strategy, lead executive board, coordinate initiatives, represent organization to university administration
task.constraints: ₱50,000 budget, volunteer board members with academic commitments, competition from 5 other tech clubs

activities: Conducted survey of 35 current members identifying 4 key pain points: repetitive events, lack of hands-on workshops, poor communication, limited career benefit
Interviewed 15 non-member CS students about barriers to joining: time commitment concerns, unclear value proposition, intimidation factor
Analyzed attendance data from past 2 years (20+ events) identifying patterns: workshops > talks, weekends > weekdays, practical > theoretical
Facilitated 2-day strategic planning retreat with executive board defining vision, mission, and 3-month objectives
Created data-driven growth strategy: (1) Revamp event format, (2) Improve communication, (3) Demonstrate career value, (4) Build inclusive culture
detailed_steps.deliverables: Strategic plan document, member feedback report, event strategy, communication plan

activities: Launched "Tech Tuesdays" weekly hands-on workshop series (8 workshops completed): Python basics, Web dev fundamentals, Git/GitHub, Data structures, etc.
Organized industry speaker series bringing in 3 professionals from local tech companies (attendance: 40, 35, 45 students)
Hosted first-ever hackathon with 25 participants forming 6 teams, ₱5,000 prizes, and 2 industry judges
Created mentorship program pairing 15 freshmen with senior CS students
Revamped meeting format from lecture-style to interactive discussions with live coding demos
detailed_steps.deliverables: 8 successful workshops, 3 industry talks, 1 hackathon event, mentorship program with 15 pairs
detailed_steps.attendance_growth: Average event attendance increased from 18 to 35 (94% improvement)

activities: Established weekly newsletter reaching 120+ CS students with upcoming events, tech news, and member spotlights
Revamped social media presence: Facebook page grew from 200 to 400 followers, Instagram started from scratch reaching 150 followers
Created recruitment campaign during orientation week: designed posters, gave 3-minute pitch to 80+ freshmen, set up booth attracting 40 sign-ups
Implemented Google Calendar integration reducing "I forgot" excuses by 60%
Started "Member Spotlight" series highlighting 5 members' projects and achievements
detailed_steps.deliverables: Weekly newsletter (16 editions), social media growth (2x followers), recruitment materials, member spotlight series
detailed_steps.engagement_metrics: Newsletter open rate 45%, social media engagement up 300%

activities: Built Excel tracking dashboard monitoring: membership count, event attendance, budget utilization, satisfaction scores
Analyzed grade distribution data for 120 CS students identifying 15 at-risk students, connected them with tutoring resources (separate but related initiative)
Surveyed members after each event collecting feedback, identified that hands-on workshops scored 4.5/5 vs talks at 3.2/5
Used attendance patterns to optimize event scheduling: switched from Monday evenings (avg 18 attendees) to Saturday mornings (avg 35 attendees)
Tracked budget spending preventing overruns: stayed within 95% of budget while increasing event frequency
detailed_steps.deliverables: Excel dashboard with 15+ metrics, post-event feedback reports, grade analysis report, optimized event calendar
detailed_steps.data_driven_decisions: 5 major strategy adjustments based on data analysis

leadership_actions: Led weekly executive board meetings (20+ meetings) with structured agendas and clear action items
Delegated effectively: assigned event planning to VP, marketing to Communications Director, mentorship to Academic Chair
Resolved conflict between 2 board members over event scheduling through facilitated discussion and compromise
Mentored 3 first-year board members on leadership skills and organizational management
Represented JPCS at 4 university-wide meetings advocating for increased funding (successfully secured additional ₱10,000)
problem_solving_examples: When industry speaker cancelled 2 days before event, pivoted to panel discussion with 3 senior students sharing internship experiences (still drew 30 attendees)
When hackathon registration was low (12 sign-ups), created referral incentive (bring a friend, both get bonus points) increasing to 25 participants
When budget was tight for end-of-year event, partnered with 2 other clubs to share costs enabling larger celebration

quantified_outcomes.member_satisfaction: 85% satisfaction rate (60/70 members rated 4+/5 in recent survey)
quantified_outcomes.budget_efficiency: Stayed within 95% of budget while doubling event output
quantified_outcomes.industry_partnerships: Established 3 new partnerships with local tech companies for mentorship and speaking opportunities
quantified_outcomes.at_risk_student_support: Identified and supported 15 students through data analysis initiative (80% improved grades)

business_impact: Revitalized JPCS as premier tech organization on campus increasing visibility and influence
Created sustainable growth model: membership pipeline with freshmen recruitment, mentorship program for retention
Improved career prospects for members through industry connections and skill-building workshops
Demonstrated value to university administration securing ₱10,000 additional funding for next year
Built strong foundation for successor leadership: documented processes, trained board, established relationships
recognition: Featured in university newspaper article about student leadership
Invited to present at Philippine Computer Society national conference (November 2025)
Received commendation from university president at Student Leadership Awards ceremony
3 industry partners expressed interest in continued collaboration
lessons_learned: Data-driven decision making works: surveying members and analyzing attendance patterns led to 2x engagement
Delegate effectively: trying to do everything myself led to burnout, empowering board members created better outcomes
Practical beats theoretical: hands-on workshops consistently outperformed lecture-style events
Consistency matters: weekly communication (newsletter, social media) built trust and kept JPCS top-of-mind
Partnerships multiply impact: collaborating with other clubs and industry created win-win opportunities
result.future_potential: Membership on track to reach 90+ by end of academic year, plans to expand to satellite chapters at 2 other universities, potential for regional hackathon with 100+ participants

career_goals.references_available: Faculty Advisor Prof. Elena Reyes (ereyes@spup.edu.ph), Vice President of JPCS Ms. Anna Mendoza (anna.mendoza@spup.edu.ph)

career_goals.team_size: Student Government Council of 12 members, supporting 1,500+ students

situation.context: St. Paul University Student Government manages budget for university-wide events serving 1,500 students
situation.problem: 20% budget overruns were common (₱30,000 over budget previous year), poor tracking led to last-minute scrambling, no visibility into spending patterns
situation.business_impact: Had to cut 2 events due to overspending, damaged credibility with administration, unable to secure additional funding
situation.stakeholders: Student Government Council (12 members), 1,500 students attending events, university administration controlling budget, 4 event committees

task.primary_responsibility: Create budget tracking system, reduce overruns, improve financial transparency, and enable data-driven budget allocation
task.specific_role: Executive Secretary with financial analysis responsibilities
success_criteria: Provide real-time budget visibility to all committees
task.constraints: No specialized software budget, must work with existing tools (Excel), data in inconsistent formats from previous years

activities: Compiled 3 years of historical spending data from paper receipts and Excel files (180+ transactions)
Standardized data format: categorized expenses into 8 categories (venue, food, marketing, equipment, prizes, transportation, supplies, contingency)
Cleaned messy data: identified 15 duplicate entries, corrected 23 data entry errors, filled 18 missing values
Analyzed spending patterns: identified that marketing consistently over budget (35% overruns) while venue under budget (10% savings)
Created baseline metrics: average cost per attendee (₱85), highest ROI events, common overspend categories
detailed_steps.deliverables: Clean dataset (3 years, 180+ transactions), analysis report with insights, spending pattern visualization

activities: Built comprehensive Excel budget tracking system with 5 worksheets: (1) Master budget, (2) Event-specific tracking, (3) Category analysis, (4) Real-time dashboard, (5) Historical comparison
Implemented dynamic formulas: SUMIF for category totals, INDEX-MATCH for event lookups, conditional formatting for over-budget warnings
Created automated alerts: red flags when event exceeds 90% of budget, yellow warnings at 75%
Designed dashboard with 8 visualizations: total spend vs budget, category breakdown, event-by-event comparison, monthly burn rate, projected year-end, top expenses, savings opportunities
Built scenario planning tool: adjust budget allocations, see real-time impact on other categories
detailed_steps.deliverables: Excel budget tracker (5 worksheets, 50+ formulas), user guide (8 pages), training materials

activities: Trained 12 Student Government members on tracker usage (2-hour workshop)
Held individual sessions with 4 event committee chairs (30 min each) on their specific dashboards
Created quick reference guide with common tasks: enter expense, check remaining budget, generate report
Established weekly review process: every Friday, analyze spending and flag potential issues
Set up shared Google Sheets version for real-time collaboration (Excel master with Google Sheets sync)
detailed_steps.deliverables: Training workshop, 4 one-on-one sessions, quick reference guide, weekly review schedule

activities: Conducted weekly budget reviews analyzing 12 events over 4 months (48 review sessions total)
Identified cost-saving opportunities: negotiated 15% discount with preferred caterer (₱18,000 annual savings), bulk-purchased supplies (₱5,000 savings)
Reallocated budget mid-year: moved ₱12,000 from under-utilized marketing to high-demand event expansion
Generated monthly financial reports for administration showing spending trends and projections (5 reports total)
Implemented pre-approval process for expenses >₱5,000 preventing impulse overspending (caught and prevented 3 potential overruns totaling ₱15,000)
detailed_steps.deliverables: 48 weekly reviews, 5 monthly reports, cost-savings initiatives documentation, revised budget allocation

problem_solving_examples: When marketing committee consistently overspent, analyzed root cause (lack of pre-approval), implemented ₱5,000 approval threshold reducing overruns 90%
When historical data was messy (different formats, missing values), developed systematic cleaning process now used for all future data
When real-time collaboration was needed, created hybrid Excel-Google Sheets solution preserving advanced formulas while enabling team access

quantified_outcomes.cost_savings: ₱23,000 saved annually (15% of budget) through negotiations and optimization
quantified_outcomes.financial_transparency: 100% of transactions tracked in real-time (vs 0% visibility previously)
quantified_outcomes.prevented_overruns: Caught and prevented 3 major overruns totaling ₱15,000
quantified_outcomes.report_generation_time: Reduced from 8 hours manual work to 15 minutes automated (97% time savings)
quantified_outcomes.event_financial_accuracy: 98% accurate budget projections (events came within 2% of estimate)
quantified_outcomes.stakeholder_satisfaction: Administration rated financial management 9/10 (up from 5/10 previous year)

business_impact: Enabled full execution of 12 planned events without cuts (vs 2 events cut previous year)
Improved credibility with administration leading to ₱20,000 additional funding for next year
Created sustainable financial management process for future councils
Enabled data-driven decisions on budget allocation based on event ROI and student preferences
Freed up 6 hours/month of Executive Secretary time through automation
recognition: Administration praised financial discipline in end-of-year review
Model budget tracker adopted by 2 other student organizations
Presented tracker methodology at Student Leadership Training for incoming officers
lessons_learned: Real-time visibility prevents problems: weekly reviews caught issues before they became crises
Automation saves time and improves accuracy: 15 minutes vs 8 hours for reports
Historical data is gold: 3 years of spending patterns revealed consistent opportunities
User training is critical: spent 6 hours training, saved 100+ hours in support and errors
Pre-approval processes work: simple ₱5,000 threshold prevented most overruns
result.future_potential: Tracker designed for scalability - can handle 2x more events and transactions, potential to expand to all student organizations (20+ groups), university administration expressed interest in similar system for departmental budgets

interview_ready_responses.why_data_analysis: My experience leading and programming our capstone project showed me how data-driven insights can improve decision-making. I enjoyed building analytics features that empowered administrators to act faster and more effectively.
interview_ready_responses.biggest_achievement: Leading the development of the Good Moral Application and Monitoring System — which improved processing efficiency by 83% and served over 200 students — taught me the importance of leadership, teamwork, and user-focused design.
interview_ready_responses.leadership_example: As JPCS President, I grew our organization’s membership by 40% through targeted initiatives and practical tech workshops that addressed real student needs.
interview_ready_responses.technical_challenge: Designing and implementing the database architecture for our system required balancing security, performance, and scalability. Researching best practices allowed us to achieve a 99.5% accuracy rate.
interview_ready_responses.career_transition: While I enjoy full-stack development, I am drawn to data analysis because I want to focus on uncovering insights that guide impactful decisions and strategies.
